title: Man Utd news: Gary Neville gives verdict on Marcus Rashford's goal vs Liverpool
text:
Marcus Rashford scored the opening goal of the game for Man Utd against Liverpool (Picture: Getty Images)

Manchester United legend Gary Neville admitted that Marcus Rashford’s goal against Liverpool on Sunday should not have stood.

Rashford put the Red Devils ahead in the first half as he poked home an excellent cross from Daniel James to give his side a surprise lead.

However, Divock Origi went down under a challenge from United defender Victor Lindelof in the build up to the goal, expecting a free-kick to be given.

VAR checked the incident after the goal was scored, and while it appeared that the Swede had indeed fouled the Belgian, the goal was not overturned.

There has been a ‘high bar’ set for VAR reviews, so only serious mistakes from referees are overturned, but Neville believes that bar is too high and any foul should result in a decision being overturned.

‘I’ve got a real problem with the bar being set on some of these fouls,’ Neville said on Sky Sports. ‘Is it enough of a foul? Either it’s a foul or it’s not.’

Divock Origi was challenged by Victor Lindelof (Picture: Getty Images)

Former Liverpool player and manager Graeme Souness agreed that it was a foul on Origi and was perplexed as to why it wasn’t given.

‘I think Lindelof does catch him, he catches the inside of his left leg anyway you look at that, that’s a foul,’ said the Scot.

‘There’s definite contact with the player, it’s a foul. He’s been kicked, below his left knee.

‘You kick someone from behind, it’s a foul, it’s not even up for discussion.’

Liverpool players were not impressed by the decision (Picture: Getty Images)

There has been some criticism of the way in which VAR is implemented in the Premier League, with the on-field referee unable to look at incidents on a screen on the side of the pitch.

Instead, the VAR official decides on whether the decision should be overturned from the remote location they are based.

Neville believes it should be the referee, in Sunday’s case Martin Atkinson, that should be able to review his own decision.

‘They’ve backed themselves into a corner, they’ve taken a position, they won’t let the referee look at the screens in the dugout,’ said Neville.

Co-commentator Jamie Carragher added: ‘They’ve left themselves open to criticism. A foul’s a foul.’

VAR worked in United’s favour on another occasion on Sunday as a Sadio Mane goal was chalked off as the Senegalese star handled the ball before putting it past David de Gea.
